articles.headline: For Iraqi Christians, Money Bought Survival
articles.snippet: Protection money paid to insurgents became a secret complication of life for Iraq’s Christian population.
articles.abstract: Protection money paid to insurgents became a secret complication of life for Iraq’s Christian population.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSUL, Iraq  As priests do everywhere, Archbishop Paulos Faraj Rahho, the leader of the Chaldean Catholics in this ancient city, gathered alms at Sunday Mass. But for years the money, a crumpled pile of multicolored Iraqi dinars, went into an envelope and then into the hand of a man who had threatened to kill him and his entire congregation.

articles.headline: Fed Shifts Its Concern to Inflation
articles.snippet: The decision to halt a stream of rate cuts signaled concern that rising oil prices will push up the costs of goods and services.
articles.abstract: The decision to halt a stream of rate cuts signaled concern that rising oil prices will push up the costs of goods and services.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s policy makers ratcheted up their worries about inflation on Wednesday without abandoning their view that the American economy is weak.

articles.headline: Gene Testing Questioned by Regulators
articles.snippet: Regulators are cracking down on companies that sell genetic tests directly to consumers, threatening to crimp the growth of one of the hottest sectors of the biotechnology industry.
articles.abstract: Regulators are cracking down on companies that sell genetic tests directly to consumers, threatening to crimp the growth of one of the hottest sectors of the biotechnology industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Regulators are cracking down on companies that sell genetic tests directly to consumers, threatening to crimp the growth of one of the hottest sectors of the biotechnology industry.

articles.headline: Obama and Clinton in Talks to Unify Party
articles.snippet: With the help of a lawyer, Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton are negotiating issues like how to repay Mrs. Clinton’s debt and her role at the convention.
articles.abstract: With the help of a lawyer, Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton are negotiating issues like how to repay Mrs. Clinton’s debt and her role at the convention.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  With the help of one of Washington’s best-connected lawyers, Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton are negotiating a thicket of complicated issues, like how to repay Mrs. Clinton’s campaign debt and her role at the Democratic convention. The talks come as they try to leave behind their intense rivalry and work out a plan to cooperate this fall.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Anheuser to Reject InBev Offer
articles.snippet: The board of the brewing company Anheuser-Busch is planning to reject InBev’s unsolicited $46.4 billion takeover bid this week, people close to the company said.
articles.abstract: The board of the brewing company Anheuser-Busch is planning to reject InBev’s unsolicited $46.4 billion takeover bid this week, people close to the company said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The board of Anheuser-Busch is planning to reject this week an unsolicited $46.4 billion takeover bid from InBev, a rival brewery based in Belgium, people close to the American company said on Wednesday.

articles.headline: When Your Camera Knows Where You Are
articles.snippet: A new technology lets your digital camera detect thousands of silent wireless networking beacons, decide exactly where you are and then transmit a batch of photos wirelessly to your computer.
articles.abstract: A new technology lets your digital camera detect thousands of silent wireless networking beacons, decide exactly where you are and then transmit a batch of photos wirelessly to your computer.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Any sufficiently advanced memory card,” Arthur C. Clarke once didn’t write, “is indistinguishable from magic.”

articles.headline: Nissan and Others Add Factories in Emerging Markets
articles.snippet: In a radical shift, Japan’s staid Big Three automakers are plowing into exotic terrain, from Saharan Africa to the former Soviet Union to the scorching plains of southern India.
articles.abstract: In a radical shift, Japan’s staid Big Three automakers are plowing into exotic terrain, from Saharan Africa to the former Soviet Union to the scorching plains of southern India.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORAGADAM, India  On a dusty sun-baked field, in a ceremony presided over by a chanting Brahmin priest tossing water and rice, the Japanese carmaker Nissan Motor made a bold step into the Indian auto market.

articles.headline: Parties Split on How to Expand Offshore Drilling
articles.snippet: Republicans want to end the ban on offshore drilling, while Democrats want to force companies to speed up exploration in certain offshore areas that they already control.
articles.abstract: Republicans want to end the ban on offshore drilling, while Democrats want to force companies to speed up exploration in certain offshore areas that they already control.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  The two political parties have settled on markedly different strategies for improving domestic oil supplies to help lower gasoline prices.
